reasoning: The critique targets a moderately central element: the essay’s percentile-based definition of “best feasible future” and its normalization to 1, combined with fixed thresholds (0.5/0.9), could in principle make “mostly-great is rare” partly a definitional artifact. If that were true, it would undercut some of the paper’s quantitative framing about how often we hit 50%/90% of potential. However, the core “no easy eutopia” thesis is not solely derived from percentile anchoring: much of the argument is about moral fragility/multiplicative factors, narrowness of targets under many moral theories (linear/unbounded, bounded variants), and empirical/structural claims (fat-tailed value-efficiency, scale effects). The critique also overstates the mechanicality: a 99.99th percentile anchor does not by itself imply that futures above 0.5 are rare; that depends on the distribution’s shape relative to the top tail. The essay’s claim is conditional on substantive assumptions (e.g., fat tails, multiplicative dimensions), so the critique refutes only part of the support, not the main case. Still, it correctly notes that the paper owes more justification for why 99.99th percentile is the normatively appropriate reference point and that heavy-tailedness plus extreme anchoring can make “mostly-great” look rarer. The critique is clear, focused, and contains little fluff.
title: Defining success by extreme percentiles mechanically guarantees rarity of success
